main_text:
Antoine Le Grand (1629–1699) was a philosopher and catholic
theologian who played an important role in propagating the Cartesian
philosophy in England and beyond during the latter half of the
seventeenth century. He was born in Douai, (at the time under rule by
the Spanish Hapsburgs), and early in life was associated with an
English community of Franciscans who had a college there. Le Grand
became a Franciscan Recollect friar prior to leaving for England as a
missionary in 1656. In England, he taught philosophy and theology,
advocating Catholicism and eventually Cartesianism, the latter being
as unpopular as the former was perilous. It is not clear how Le Grand
came to Cartesianism, but the first evidence of his adoption of the
new philosophy was in his Institutio Philosophiae, published
in London in 1672. His early works show affinities to the philosophies
of Seneca and Epicurus. He is noted for his polemical exchanges with
Samuel Parker and John Sergeant, and for having given
Descartes’s work a Scholastic form to further its acceptance in
the schools.
